meanings.definition: (archaic) To inflict; to vent; to hurl.
meanings.english_definition: To inflict; to vent; to hurl.

etymology.value: From Middle English awreken, from Old English āwrecan (“to drive out, expel, punish, avenge”), from Proto-Germanic *uzwrekaną (“to drive out, avenge”), from *wrekaną (“to drive, push, persecute”), from Proto-Indo-European *wreg- (“to push, shove, drive, track down”).

usage_notes.explanation: "a-wreak" is an archaic verb meaning to inflict or vent. It is rarely used in modern English.

readability_explanation.text: The word "a-wreak" is archaic and rarely encountered in modern English. It is primarily found in older literature.

example_sentences.sentence: He vowed to a-wreak his anger on those who had wronged him.
example_sentences.translation: 彼は自分を不当に扱った者たちに怒りをぶつけることを誓った。
